page.title: 04CHENIES MANOR.
page.content: Isenhampstead-Cheyne gradually became known as Chenies. When Chenies Manor was built,it was not thought that it would need any fortifications,so there is no moat or other defence systems. However there are passages under the Manor House but these may have been for drainage. Also,there is in the house, a priest hole,which is unusual because the family were Protestants,and would therefore not have needed the use of a priest hole.The Manor House was built of brick,in a Dieper pattern,and the chimneys sculptured by a local craftsman.These were greatly admired by Henry VIII on a visit to Chenies,and he had similar ones built on Hampton Court.There is supposed to be a ghost of Henry VIII,who had an ulcerated leg,trying to climb the stairs.
